intro: Sidalcea rhizomata, commonly known as the purple poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its legume fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant features showy, violet to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are trifoliate, with three oval-shaped leaflets, and it has a fibrous root system. Sidalcea rhizomata is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes.
